description: Bill and Yasu encounter Liz, another "peculiar." Liz's eccentricities (including her disturbingly carnivorous eating habits) prove alienating at first, but their commonalities start to seem stronger than their differences.
name: Part Two

description: In the final showdown with the malevolent creature that attacked their friends, Bill and Yasu must struggle to wield the destructive power of their joined form and save everyone they hold dear.
name: Part Three

description: Bill, Yasu, Liz and Carina are living fairly normal lives for supernatural beings, but another attack on them breaks the group apart. Yasu does the impossible and leaves Bill.
name: Part Four

description: Bill's tutelage under David comes to a sudden end when Yasu shows up in search of Liz. David shows his true colors, forcing Bill and Yasu to merge again to save their friend.
name: Part Five

description: Bill and Yasu end their years of training in solitude to confront David, who is about to marry Carina, Bill's girlfriend and mother of his child.
name: Part Six

description: Petropolis. October 12, 1991. Lost his family, job and mind, August Kantser, the Captain of Gendarmerie, receives medical treatment in clinic for insane persons. He is released for urgent and dangerous investigation of three incidents had torn Petropolis last night. The arson in the dark flophouse, the carnage in night club, and shooting in the courtyard killed almost hundred people. In the courtyard August finds living witness who points to the organizer, Grigory Skuratov, better known as the Skornyak (Furrier), the leader of the gang Nordic Cartel and one of the candidates for city governor. August and his partners, Snow White and Felix Bazhov go to check up reliability of the information

Tank Girl is BACK with an all-new, sumptuously coloured look! But that's not all that's about to change... Join us for an epic dose of fun and games as a trip to see the filming of a TV gameshow catapults Tank Girl, Booga and all her friends into an insane mission of vengeance and... spiritual awakening? Will Tank Girl ever be the same again?

Tank Girl and Booga are on a monstrous mission of vengeance against Charlie Happy, the gameshow host who did them wrong! They're out to hang, draw and take no quarter... while on a journey of spiritual awakening?!

Following her humiliation on a TV game-show and the subsequent public slaughter of the show's host, Charlie Happy, Tank Girl has had an epiphany. Now she's travelling from town to town doing good deeds, trying to avoid violence and spreading her own unique form of love, peace and spirituality in the name of Carioca!

All U Leen Happy - the vengeful widow of Charlie Happy - wants is bloody revenge, against Tank Girl and all of her crew. She and her army of ruthless assassins have sworn to kill Tank Girl, or die trying! Can she possibly succeed?

After becoming a being of contemplation, spirituality and ass-kicking powers, Tank Girl must throw it all away in order to finish murdering the monstrously overweight U-Leen Harpy and her assorted hired cronies. Thank goodness!

Can Tank Girl ever get back to normal? Will U Leen Happy be conquered at last? Will the gang get off scott-free for a country-wide murder spree? ...Probably, but you'll never know unless you read on and find out!

The original Tank Girl comics, in stunning black and white as they were meant to be seen! Ripped from the pages of classic cult comics mag Deadline and tarted up to their original glory, don't miss these anarchic tales in all their world-striding majesty!

The original Tank Girl comics, remastered and tarted up to their seminal glory! This issue: Tank Girl and Booga take on a BOUNTY HUNTING TOURNAMENT, go in search of a refined culinary experience, and find out what actually happened to THE SMITHS. Don't miss the unnatural excitement stirring in your pants - and between these digital pages!

The original Tank Girl comics, remastered and tarted up to their seminal glory! This issue: Booga and Tank Girl go off-piste with a skiing holiday, Jet Girl tries an experiment, an alien tracks down Tank Girl thanks to her vital statistics, and more! Don't miss the non-stop, boundary-breaking action adventure!

The original Tank Girl comics, as they were meant to be seen! This issue: go walkabout with Tank Girl and meet the whole gang. Plus, what is THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO SUB GIRL, and why is Booga wearing a dress?

The original Tank Girl comics, in stunning black and white as they were meant to be seen! Ripped from the pages of classic cult comics mag Deadline and tarted up to their original glory, don't miss these anarchic tales in all their world-striding majesty!

The dead have become restless. An unending cycle of murder and injustice permeate a large cemetery. The cries of the dead will no longer go unanswered.

A man, resurrected from an eternal slumber, becomes the dark taskmaster of vengeance for those who, even in death, cannot forget fear. Cursed with spectral tattoos of unlimited power, Cemetarious exacts retribution for others, unaware that his own past will one day haunt him from the afterlife.
name: Ronin Studios

description: When the earth is in an ice age and many are searching for the legendary land, Sol-Thel, a small group of fighters discovers there is more in Sol-Thel than they bargained for and that the danger is now hunting them. Not only do they have to face the sabretooths and other strange creatures now walking the earth, but they must also watch out for soldiers of both humans and demons. Magics have returned to the land but their resident magician can only do so much against creatures made up of magic. When they discover a bounty on her head they realize there is something special about her, and they realize they much fight the danger in Sol-Thel, even if it is a dragon commanding an army of darkness.

Collecting every strip from December 8, 1980, through December 31, 1981, in chronological order, with a new cover insert by Breathed. Berkeley Breathed's Bloom County burst onto the American comic scene in December 1980 and it soon became one of the most popular comic strips of all time. The endearing and quirky denizens of the strip included Milo Bloom, Steve Dallas, Michael Binkley, Cutter John, Bill the Cat, and Opus the Penguin. Bloom County was a strip that dealt with many issues relevant to the period. Occasional "Context comments" are added throughout this collection, giving the reader a greater understanding of the time. This is the first time Bloom County has been collected in a digital library. IDW will add more volumes, one year per app. Each newspaper strip is reproduced in chronological order from first to last. Great effort has been made to ensure the highest production values are achieved. The Bloom County Library is the latest offering in IDW Publishing's series of Digital Graphic Novels. We've assembled the best of favorite brands and respected creators for you to collect on your digital bookshelf.
name: Volume One: 1980-1981

description: Collecting every strip from January 1, 1982, through December 31, 1982, in chronological order, with a new cover insert by Breathed. Berkeley Breathed's Bloom County burst onto the American comic scene in December 1980 and it soon became one of the most popular comic strips of all time. The endearing and quirky denizens of the strip included Milo Bloom, Steve Dallas, Michael Binkley, Cutter John, Bill the Cat, and Opus the Penguin. Bloom County was a strip that dealt with many issues relevant to the period. Occasional "Context comments" are added throughout this collection, giving the reader a greater understanding of the time. This is the first time Bloom County has been collected in a digital library. IDW will add more volumes, one year per app. Each newspaper strip is reproduced in chronological order from first to last. Great effort has been made to ensure the highest production values are achieved. The Bloom County LibraryScott Dunbier is the latest offering in IDW Publishing's series of Digital Graphic Novels. We've assembled the best of favorite brands and respected creators for you to collect on your digital bookshelf.
name: Volume Two: 1982

description: Bloom County: The Complete Library, Volume Three collects every strip from July 1984 through February 1986. Many fondly remembered strips are in this volume, including the classic 1984 presidential elections featuring possibly the finest running mates ever for such a campaign: Opus and Bill the Cat. Plus a cornucopia of ingenious satire featuring the rest of the Bloom County cast: Steve Dallas, Mio, Binkley, Oliver, Cutter John, and all the rest. Additionally, this volume contains many insightful, biting, and downright hysterical annotations by Berkeley Breathed as he comments on his strips in his own uniquely irreverent way. Context pages, for perspective, are sprinkled throughout the book.
name: Volume Three: 1983

description: Specially formatted digital edition! Collecting every strip from January 1, 1984, through December 31, 1984, in chronological order, with a new cover insert by Breathed. Berkeley Breathed?s Bloom County burst onto the American comic scene in December 1980 and it soon became one of the most popular comic strips of all time. The endearing and quirky denizens of the strip included Milo Bloom, Steve Dallas, Michael Binkley, Cutter John, Bill the Cat, and Opus the Penguin. Bloom County was a strip that dealt with many issues relevant to the period. Occasional ?Context comments? are added throughout this collection, giving the reader a greater understanding of the time. This is the first time Bloom County has been collected in a digital library, one year per digital volume. Each newspaper strip is reproduced in chronological order from first to last. Great effort has been made to ensure the highest production values are achieved.
name: Volume Four: 1984

Great effort has been made to ensure the highest production values are achieved.
name: Volume Nine: 1989

description: Robert Williams talks about comics, cars and art; Mark Newgarden talks about comics, cards, and Nancy; Richard Sala sketches and doesn't talk.

Acclaimed Mage and Grendel creator Matt Wagner receives his first substantial, heavily-illustrated, career-spanning interview in January 1994's Comics Journal. Only here will you find out the whys and hows of Wagner's success from his first Comico Primer work to feature projects such as Doctor Mid-Nite and... Mage II?!? You've met Tom Tomorrow through his strip This Modern World which appears in alternative weeklies throughout America but you haven't really gotten to know him until you've read him interviewed by Journal editor Gary Groth. Plus, meet the artist who drew the critically-acclaimed Kings in Disguise comic book for Kitchen Sink Press, Dan Burr; his sketchbook appears in this issue, with a selection of images both profound and witty. And as usual, The Comics Journal features virtually the only investigative news source in comic books; the only critical, in-depth reviews; the controversial letters column "Blood and Thunder"; and "Hit List" and "Cool Comics Shops," the guide to the best comics and comic shops out there.

A two-sided flip-book issue. On one side: Who is Paul Mavrides? The Comics Journal tells all in April 1994, but to give you a hint, he happens to be the lone cartoonist taking on the California State Tax Board's landmark decision that comic books are not artistic expression. Need more? How 'bout: The Church of the SubGenius, The Fabulous Furry Freak Brothers in "The Idiots Abroad," graphic design for director Alex Cox, Anarchy Comics, RE/SEARCH, The New Yorker, velvet paintings, The Realist, American Splendor, gum cards, Village Voice, Heavy Metal, and High Times? If you want to hear from a man behind the scenes on all these phenomena, pick up The Comics Journal #167. You'll also find the second and concluding half of the definitive interview with Burne Hogarth, creator of Dynamic Anatomy and Tarzan in the comics!

On the other side: Remembering Jack Kirby. Reminiscences, tributes and critical commentary from Will Eisner, Neil Gaiman, Paul Chadwick, Steve Rude, Chester Brown, Rick Veitch, Don Heck, Joe Sinnott, Jim Woodring, Marie Severin, Alan Moore, R.C. Harvey, Mark Schultz, Alex Toth, Richard Corben, Stan Lee and many more, with a cover portrait by Jaime Hernandez.

The Kirby tribute and the Mavrides and Hogarth interviews may be issue #167's features, but the real star of TCJ remains the range of regular features that mark it as the industry's best all-around magazine. The Journal's Newswatch section is the only source of real journalism on comic books, one that keeps readers who care deeply about the art of comics informed on the business and legal decisions that affect the entire industry. Plus, the Journal's review section is the only place you'll find people who take comics seriously discussing what comics are and what comics can be. And the Journal's "Hit List" section provides a reliable guide for sifting through the mass of comics junk to help you find the good stuff. The only logical conclusion: keep up with The Comics Journal, and keep up with the state of the art in comics.
Special double cover issue featuring covers by and interviews with Naughty Bits's Roberta Gregory and ElfQuest's Wendy and Richard Pini, as well as a Guy Davis sketchbook.

The Comics Journal for June 1994 features the longest and most in-depth interview to date with fan-favorite writer Neil Gaiman. Gaiman has become one of the most admired writers working in comic books today; learn what he sees as the potential and failings of the comic medium. Be surprised at what Gaiman thinks about pornography, censorship, and creative freedom on Sandman. Hear Gaiman's take on the ongoing question of creators' rights, work-for-hire and just how bad the various comic publishers really are. This most revealing interview along with all the usual news, reviews, and features (including a back-up interview with Sol Harrison, former president of DC Comics) comes wrapped in an intricate cover portrait by Michael Zulli (Gaiman's collaborator on Sweeney Todd.

The Clive Barker interview (with ghastly cover art by Barker). Also interviewed: Dame Darcy. Plus: Gary Groth compares Jim Shooter to Nixon (with ghastly flip-cover art by Bill Willingham); comics' first move online in the days of CompuServe; Marvel vs. Comics Unlimited; Terry Gilliam sketchbook; more!

Two of the industry's most successful self-publishers sound off in TCJ #173 as Jeff Smith, creator of the critically acclaimed and wildly popular cartoon fantasy Bone, and Martin Wagner, creator of the anthropomorphic drama Hepcats, tell all in their definitive Journal interviews. Also included: a sketchbook from King and Black Dogs creator Ho Che Anderson, and all the regular award-winning news and reviews.

War! What is it good for? Well, to sell comics, for one thing. In this issue, Vietnam Journal creator Don Lomax talks about how he's been able to translate his horrific experiences in Viet Nam into a popular alternative comic. As a special added attraction, the interview is conducted by Itchy Planet editor and liberal activist Leonard Rifas, who can be counted on to delve into the political and ethical ramifications of the comic. Lomax drew a special Vietnam Journal cover for this issue as well. Also in this issue, news, reviews, more feature articles, and a second interview with Bob Foster, the creator of Myron the Moose and editor for Walt Disney's comics line.

Feathers fly in this issue of The Comics Journal as Steve Bissette and Scott McCloud discuss creators' rights with Gary Groth and then engage in a debate on the matter with (among others) Bill Sienkiewicz, Marvel's Steve Saffel, and Vortex's Bill Marks. And there's also a report on the Bill Watterson/Mort Walker slugfest at the Festival of Cartoon Art, in which the creator of Calvin & Hobbes decried the wretched state of comic strips and the loutish greed of syndicates, while the man behind Beetle Bailey rose to give an opposing viewpoint. The cover is an unusual jam between Bissette and McCloud.

"Confessions of a Sex-Crazed Housewife": Peter Bagge interviews Aline Kominsky-Crumb (read it at TCJ.com); "Adult Comics Under Siege: Two Florida Retailers Busted"; "A Decade of Weirdo: an Autopsy by Dr. Jim Woodring"; "Big Words: Part II of the Alan Moore Interview"; "Homo-Sequentiality; A Gay Voice In A Mainstream Wilderness"; Lloyd Dangle sketchbook; and much more in this jam-packed issue!

A stunning full-color painting by Timothy Truman leads off an issue that features an interview with the creator of Wilderness, Scout, and Hawkworld. Truman has long been known for his vigorous stance on creator's rights, as well as being one of the few star artists to take matters into his own hands and start his very own publishing company. Truman is an intelligent, articulate artist, grilled with customary mercilessness by Gary Groth about the art and business of comics. This extra-special issue also includes such goodies as: Jack Jackson's feature-length review of Giraud and Charlier's "Blueberry" series; an interview with Canadian cartoonist Bernie Mireault (of The Jam fame); an international focus on Caribbean comics; and a sketchbook section by none other than Dan Clowes!
An interview with comics' master fantasist, P. Craig Russell; "Dirty Dogpatch" uncovers the lowdown on hidden smut in Al Capp's Li'l Abner; Kim Deitch sketchbook part 2!

This issue, one of the most exciting graphic talents of the past two decades is interviewed: Charles Burns, whose work in RAW, Taboo, and Death Rattle had by this time introduced him to a generation of comics aficionados. Burns provided an original cover for this issue of the Journal, which features a memoir of comics legend Sheldon Mayer and Doug Allen and insane Gary Lieb sketchbook pages as well. Plus a review of Dan Clowes's Eightball and alternative women cartoonists in England. As always, that's just part of the story, as this issue also includes the usual informative news, feisty reviews, combative letters column, and more!

Millions of readers have been creeped out by Gahan Wilson's drawings in Playboy and elsewhere over the years. Wilson is also an accomplished writer and critic, and this issue's feature-length interview finds him at his most articulate. This is a guy who was roaming "The Far Side" of humor before Gary Larson was even born! Also in this issue, an interview with Steven creator Doug Allen, plus, as usual, the most perceptive reviews, the liveliest letters column, and a sketchbook section featuring Mark Martin!

Also includes "These Gauls Are Crazy!," an autobiographical Colin Upton story

How many underground cartoon characters have become household names? The Fabulous Furry Freak Brothers, Mister Natural... and Zippy the Pinhead, read daily by millions in newspapers around the country. Bill Griffith is one of the founding members of the original underground (as well as the co-editor, with Art Spiegelman, of groundbreaking Raw precursor Arcade) and in this very lengthy interview, Griffith talks candidly to Gary Groth about the early days of the underground, the pitfalls of fame, the ever-delayed Zippy movie deal, and much more. Also: A peek into the sketchbooks of Kyle Baker, the very funny creator of Why I Hate Saturn, whose work has appeared in everything from DC's Shadow to Esquire.

Twenty-five years after the premiere of Zap comics, this issue of the Only Magazine About Comics That Matters (or are we being immodest?) features a very rare Robert Crumb appearance on a convention panel. The ol' pooperoo is at his most gregarious, and regales an enraptured audience with his own experiences, witticisms, and insights on such diverse subjects as politics, Bush (I), violence in America, and the state of comics art. A perfect companion piece for the legendary Crumb interview issue of The Comics Journal. Also in this issue, an interview with superb editorial cartoonist Ed Sorel, a sketchbook section with "Nard 'n' Pat" creator Jay Lynch, as well as the usual news, reviews, "Hot Picks," previews, feature articles, columns and more.

Lois's investigative skills pay off when she gets a lead from a clue picked up in Lex's office. Oliver and Chloe delve back into the mind of the Chloe from Earth-2! Superman and Bart, concerned about what they encountered in hyper-speed, head to a very special location to locate a man who may be able to help them.
name: Haunted Part 6

description: Special double cover issue! After spending the last several years stomping through the conventions of the superhero genre with The One, Brat Pack and Maximortal, cartoonist Rick Veitch has plunged into the equally frightening worlds of the subconscious and self-publishing. The king of King Hell Press sits down with the Journal for a career-spanning interview, including a detailed discussion of his latest work, particularly the dream diary Roarin' Rick's Rare Bit Fiends. And he provides a cover! The second cover subject is legendary hardcore artist S. Clay Wilson, interviewed / dissected / reviewed in a "you have to see it to believe it" feature article. The flip cover itself is a photo Wilson describes as "so grotesque it looks like one of my works." And don't forget the Journal's regular battery of news, analysis, reviews and letters!

We kept digging around our warehouse and look what popped up one of the all-time classic issues of The Comics Journal. Is Stan Lee "Stan the Man" or is he just "The Man"? This issue searches for the answer with essays about Lee's media savvy and his relation with Jack Kirby, a classic interview from 1968 and testimonials from nearly every cartoonist around in 1995. Drew Friedman provides the coolest looking cover ever. Excelsior! Plus: more Art Spiegelman, Joost Swarte.

The Comics Journal takes one of its always impressive forays into the world of cartoon illustration: an exclusive interview with the dean of American caricaturists, celebrity portrait artist Al Hirschfeld. In addition to our chat with the "Line King," the Journal is proud to present the major interview with one of the most important figures in comics' last 20 years: Tales of the Beanworld cartoonist and Image Executive Director Larry Marder, in a no-holds-barred account of where he's been and why he's done what he's done. It's the interview everyone in comics was talking about. Also, the best features, news coverage and reviews in comics!

This is the legendary mega-interview that was talked about for months: from Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, to stardom, to Tundra, to Underwhere and beyond Gary Groth sits down for a long, revealing discussion with Kevin Eastman, adorned with an amazing front cover masterpiece by Simon Bisley! And you must never forget the usual battery of reviews and news that have made the Journal the best little comics magazine in the world!

The Journal interviews three of the greatest craftsmen in comics history: the power of Russ Manning, the delicious linework of Noel Sickles, and a lost interview with the cartooning genius behind Wash Tubbs and Captain Easy and Buz Sawyer, Roy Crane. If you're a fan of the art form, don't miss this one. Also, deep in the heart of Texas, two amazing artists have been producing comics with little fanfare: Roy Tompkins of Trailer Trash and Mack White of Villa of the Mysteries talk about conspiracies and art in a roundtable setting.

The Journal presents three big interviews drawing on all corners of the alternative comics field. We catch cover artist Peter Bagge at the crossroads of his comics career he just ended the incredibly popular Hate: what's next for this fan-favorite creator? We also track down the finest young talent in editorial cartoons Ted Rall and enjoy a razor-sharp exchange with one of society's finest commentators about his satirically-charged newspaper work and his laugh-a-minute comics albums and longer stories like "The Worst Thing I've Ever Done." Our interview with underground legend Spain Rodriguez, begun in issue #204, concludes in this issue. Finally, we corner Vertigo mainstay Peter Milligan in the midst of his 1998 re-emergence into popular comics consciousness. Plus all the jokes, hard-nosed news, and reviews you've come to expect from the award-winning magazine!

The Journal sits down for not one, but TWO interviews with legendary cartoonist Frank Miller! First, Chris Brayshaw sits down to talk with Miller about Sin City, 300, Dark Knight, Ronin, Daredevil, and much more as Miller discusses his artistic career in past, present, and future terms. Then, Journal founder Gary Groth follows up with an interview about everything but Miller's comics: his thoughts on the First Amendment, work-for-hire, and many other of Miller's favorite subjects. Featuring an all-new cover by Miller! Add to this a back-up interview with The Magic Whistle's hilarious Sam Henderson, the usually stellar news coverage, the best reviews in the industry, international comics exposure and several other great features and you have another award-winning issue of the longest-running and most respected magazine about comics in the world!

Evan Dorkin talks and talks and talks... Jesus! The creator behind Milk & Cheese, Pirate Corp$ and Action Girl sits down with Tom Spurgeon to bitch about so much more than the industry: comics readers, geriatrics, comics shops, elementary school, comics publishers... Then Sheldon Moldoff takes us on a trip through over 60 years of the comics industry. From Hawkman to Batman to Big Boy, this legend of the Golden and Silver Ages has worked on just about everything under the sun. Plus news, opinions, and more.

The Journal presents a very special and long overdue feature interview with noted EC and Cracked artist John Severin, conducted by Gary Groth. Sporting an original cover by Severin, the interview discusses all facets of Severin's career, from his earliest days landing a spot in Harvey Kurtzman's studio and playing a major role in the success of EC's war comics, to helping shape the early days of Mad magazine, to achieving "living legend" status at Cracked magazine, and a helluva lot in between (including a long stint with Warren publications). Backing up Severin is (then-) newcomer Tony Millionaire, who first gained notoriety with his syndicated weekly strip Maakies, and subsequently caught on with his sleeper hit Sock Monkey series from Dark Horse. Find out why comics used to be better, liquor goes hand in hand with cartooning, and more. Plus, the most important news and reviews in the industry, making the Journal a resource you can't afford to miss!

With an Alex Ross original cover, the Journal descends upon influential world of intelligent superhero comics! Harvey and Eisner Award-winning and critically-acclaimed writer Kurt Busiek talks with the Journal in the definitive and longest interview of his career about Marvels, The Avengers, Astro City, everything in between and his plans for the future not to be missed! Also, Gary Groth interviews the young, Xeric Grant-winning creator of Girlhero and Queen of the Black Black fame, Megan Kelso. TCJ continues to be the industry's strongest source for news, reviews and essays on the comics art form and industry.

The functional and the dysfunctional! On the 20th anniversary of For Better or For Worse, the Journal uncovers some things you didn't know about Lynn Johnston in an expansive feature interview! Johnston also provides the cover for this issue! And don't miss the 10 never-before-seen pages from Alex Ross's sketchbook! Plus, an interview with industry recluse Maxon Crumb gets the dirt you didn't see in the Crumb movie. We couldn't come up with a more bizarre contrast if we tried! From every corner of the industry, TCJ continues to be your strongest source for comics news, criticism and theory!

This issue is just chock-full of interviews: The Trilogy, Stardust and Book of Ballads and Sagas creator Charles Vess discusses his career and self-publishing; Castle Waiting writer/artist Linda Medley on her new Vertigo book; and Bone impresario Jeff Smith on the animating of those "stupid, stupid rat creatures." Plus a delightful cover from Vess himself!
Hilarious Kyle Baker interview, plus remembering the Golden Age with Pierce Rice; Charles Schulz retires Peanuts; David Boswell talks shop; Ted White on his reign at Heavy Metal.
Decade in review. Eddie Campbell interviewed.
Erik Larsen ("What's Wrong with the Mainstream") and James Kochalka ("What's Wrong with Craft") now there's a duo. Plus Busiek on Gorilla, a history of Image Comics, industry news.
Interview with Alex Ross, part 1; Bob Levin chats with "underground grrrl" Trina Robbins; Lloyd Dangle (Troubletown) interviewed.
Larry Gonick interviewed, part two of the Alex Ross interview, Dan DeCarlo vs. Archie.

Hacking! Gil Kane interviewed, John Buscema's Chalk Talk, CC Beck's roman clef on comics biz, "World's Mightiest Fat Head." Plus coverage of San Diego Comic Con 2000, Kochalka's cartoon diary, the TCJ quiz, more.
Everything you always wanted to know about Tom Sutton but were afraid to ask; catching up with Mike Allred; industry news, more.

In this issue, The Comics Journal presents a triumvirate of creators not usually mentioned in the same breath: famed Tomb of Dracula artist Gene Colan, World War 3 Illustrated editor/writer/artist Seth Tobocman and ABC Comics writer/creator Alan Moore! In a feature-length interview, Colan covers his career with Larry Rodman; Tobocman waxes revolutionary with Kent Worcester; and, in a brief chat, Moore discusses the ABC books, and how comics can be fun after all. Also, a crack staff of TCJ reviewers take on the ABC books in a critical roundup of the entire line. All this, plus the first half of our Y2K roundup, is yours in Comics Journal #231.

Special 25th Anniversary "Ego Issue"! It's all about us, us, us this time around as we write and rewrite history. First we have testimonials from people whom we promised positive reviews to say nice things about us. We did not, of course, follow through. Then, extended, thought-provoking introspections on how we have changed the world for the better. Also, opposing views. Plus, an adorable and scandalous picture album, a timeline of everything that has ever happened that matters, contributions from Dave Sim and Scott McCloud, and other stuff.

This month, Highwater Books' alternative publishing magnate Tom Devlin says goodbye to summer with short interviews of Spanish cartoonist/designer Mariscal, English cartoonist/philosopher Glenn Dakin and Japanese cartoonist/scatologist Enomoto. Also in this issue, we provide an overview of the comics of Tove Jansson (Moomin creator), and Seth takes a look at the comics of John Stanley. Brian Ralph goes to Gary Panter's studio to try on the Pee Wee Herman merchandise, Greg Cook looks at how fine art has influenced comics and why cartoonists get jealous when that influence shows up, Ron Rege tries to track down Mark Beyer, and Jef Czekaj (of Hypertruck) explains how to get a guaranteed grant for your comics project. Finally, Tom Devlin explains how the deification of EC Comics has stunted the growth of comics for over 40 years. With a cover and interior design by Jordan Crane, this issue is a must have for anyone who's ever read alternative comics.
